usesPermission.description: This application can close other running applications on the device.
Allows all possible interactions across users.
Prevents the user from switching to another app.
Allows an application to expand or collapse the status bar.
This application can keep the device from going into sleep mode. If used improperly this could drain the device's power.

This application can add, remove, change events that are accessible on the device, including those of friends or co-workers. This may allow the application to send messages that appear to come from calendar owners, or modify events without the owners' knowledge.
This application can read calendar events or in combination with other permissions send it off the device.
This application can write to external storage such as an SD Card.
Allows mounting and un-mounting file systems for removable storage.

This application can create network sockets and use custom network protocols. The browser and other applications provide means to send data to the internet, so this permission is not required to send data to the internet.
This permission will allow the application to read the state of the networks the device is connected to.
Allows the app to access the download manager and to use it to download files. Malicious apps can use this to disrupt downloads and access private information.
Allows the app to access the download manager's advanced functions. Malicious apps can use this to disrupt downloads and access private information.
Allows the app to send notifications about completed downloads. Malicious apps can use this to confuse other apps that download files.
Allows an application to install packages.
Allows an application to delete packages.
This application has the functionality to allow it to automatically start itself after a reboot.
Allows access to the list of accounts in the Accounts Service.
This application can authenticate through the accounts on the device. This permission allows the application to add and remove accounts, confirm credentials and retrieve access tokens.
This application can perform operations like adding and removing accounts, and deleting their password.
Allows an application to request auth tokens from the AccountManager
This permission will allow the application to obtain all information on all Wi-Fi networks within range.

Allows an application to collect component usage statistics. Declaring the permission implies intention to use the API and the user of the device can grant permission through the Settings application.
This application can generate a pop-up window that could potentially overlay other applications.
Allows an application to open windows that are for use by parts of the system user interface.
Allows an application to find out the space used by any package.
Allows an application to delete cache files.
Allows an application to broadcast sticky intents. Sticky intents can make your device run slow or and cause instability by introducing memory leaks.
Allows the app to retrieve information about currently and recently running tasks. This may allow the app to discover information about which applications are used on the device.
Allows access to the vibrator
Required to be able to reboot the device.
This application can modify the systems settings data. Malicious applications could modify the system configuration. Usage of this functionality should be reviewed in the technical report.
Allows the app to perform actions across different users on the device. Malicious apps may use this to violate the protection between users.
Allows an application to take screen shots and more generally get access to the frame buffer data.
Allows an application to read or write the secure system settings.
This application has the permission to delete personal user data. Review the risk profile and technical reports to validate functionality.
This application can modify the preferred applications. Malicious apps may silently change the applications that are run, spoofing your existing applications to collect private data from you.
Allows query of any normal app on the device, regardless of manifest declarations.
Allows an app to post notifications
Allows an application to watch and control how activities are started globally in the system.
Allows an app to use device supported biometric modalities.
This application can use fingerprint authentication.
This application can read from external storage mediums such as SD Cards.

thirdParty.name: Facebook SDK
thirdParty.description:
Facebook SDK for Android helps you build engaging social apps and get more installs.
Includes Bolts, Audience Network, and Facebook packages. Requires Android API 9.

thirdParty.name: Google Zxing
thirdParty.description: ZXing (pronounced "zebra crossing") is an open-source, multi-format 1D/2D barcode image processing library implemented in Java, with ports to other languages.

thirdParty.name: Google Protocol Buffers
thirdParty.description: Protocol Buffers - Google's data interchange format. https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/

thirdParty.name: Tencent
thirdParty.description: Tencent Founded in November 1998, is one of China's largest Internet service provider, is also China's largest Internet companies service users currently.

thirdParty.name: Bump Technologies
thirdParty.description: Our mission at Bump has always been to build the simplest tools for sharing the information you care about with other people and devices.On January 31, 2014, Bump and Flock will be removed from the App Store and Google Play. After this date, neither app will work, and all user data will be deleted.

thirdParty.name: SquareUp
thirdParty.description:
Easy-to-use tools for every corner of your business.
From mobile point-of-sale tools and appointment scheduling to fast deposits and online invoicing, Square has everything you need to take care of every little thing.

thirdParty.name: Google Gson
thirdParty.description: Gson is a Java library that can be used to convert Java Objects into their JSON representation. It can also be used to convert a JSON string to an equivalent Java object. Gson can work with arbitrary Java objects including pre-existing objects that you do not have source-code of.

thirdParty.name: Crashlytics
thirdParty.description: Crashlytics for Android delivers deep, rich crash reporting across devices in real ­time. Crashlytics performs a detailed analysis of every thread on every Android device to identify the most important issues.

thirdParty.name: Apache Commons Logging
thirdParty.description:
When writing a library it is very useful to log information. However there are many logging implementations out there, and a library cannot impose the use of a particular one on the overall application that the library is a part of.

The Logging package is an ultra-thin bridge between different logging implementations. A library that uses the commons-logging API can be used with any logging implementation at runtime. Commons-logging comes with support for a number of popular logging implementations, and writing adapters for others is a reasonably simple task.

thirdParty.name: Retrofit
thirdParty.description: Retrofit is a type-safe REST client for Android and Java. This uses annotation to describe HTTP server calls. This is an elegant solution for managing REST API calls in in android application.

thirdParty.name: Okio
referenceURL: Okio is a new library that complements java.io and java.nio to make it much easier to access

thirdParty.name: Kotlin
thirdParty.description: This app references the Kotlin framework. Kotlin  is a statically typed programming language for modern multi-platform applications

thirdParty.name: Green Robot
thirdParty.description: OPEN SOURCE LIBRARIES TO SPEED UP APP DEVELOPERS

thirdParty.name: IO Reactivex
thirdParty.description: An API for asynchronous programming with observable streams

scanDetails.description: The app was found to contain Windows/PE binary in assets.
This app has enabled the backup feature in Android. The backup data may expose sensitive information which potentially could be accessed by an adversary.

compliance.registrationNumber: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor
CWE-538: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Externally-Accessible File or Directory

compliance.riskDescription: Implement technical policies and procedures for electronic information systems that maintain electronic protected health information to allow access only to those persons or software programs that have been granted access rights as specified in §164.308(a)(4).

compliance.riskCategory: V2: Data Storage and Privacy Requirements
compliance.riskDescription: No sensitive data is included in backups generated by the mobile operating system.
This app has enabled the backup feature in Android. The backup data may expose sensitive information which potentially could be accessed by an adversary.

scanDetails.description: The app uses the primary external storage.

compliance.riskDescription:
Article 25, Section 1 states:  "….both at the time of the determination of the means for processing and at the time of the processing itself, implement appropriate technical and organisational measures, such as pseudonymisation, which are designed to implement data-protection principles". 
If personal data is being saved, then it should be pseudonymised.  Saving the data to external storage offers no permission level security to protect that data from a potential attacker.

Implement technical policies and procedures for electronic information systems that maintain electronic protected health information to allow access only to those persons or software programs that have been granted access rights as specified in §164.308(a)(4).

compliance.riskName: Files created on external storage are world readable and writeable meaning any app can read or write to them. Additionally, since external storage can be removed from the device and connected to any other computer, it is not possible to enforce access control for data stored on external storage.
compliance.riskDescription: External Data Storage

scanDetails.description: This app implements the checkCallingOrSelf(Uri)Permission(). This method is used to determine the permissions of the app being referenced. This method also has the ability to grant the calling application the same permissions as this app.
This application can potentially gains access to the device ID.

compliance.riskDescription:
Article 25, Section 1 states:  "…both at the time of the determination of the means for processing and at the time of the processing itself, implement appropriate technical and organisational measures, such as pseudonymisation, which are designed to implement data-protection principles". 
The Device ID number can be considered a personal identifier when combined with other data points. This GDPR article states the data should be pseudonymised if it is being stored or sent off device.

scanDetails.description: The application may be using certificate pinning.

compliance.riskDescription: The app either uses its own certificate store, or pins the endpoint certificate or public key, and subsequently does not establish connections with endpoints that offer a different certificate or key, even if signed by a trusted CA.

scanDetails.description: This app can access and read the contents of the global clipboard.

The permission to one or more content provider's data is granted. This could potentially lead to the disclosure of information as this allows other applications (e.g., a malicious app) on the device to request and access data.

compliance.riskDescription:
Article 25, Section 1 states:  "…both at the time of the determination of the means for processing and at the time of the processing itself, implement appropriate technical and organisational measures, such as pseudonymisation, which are designed to implement data-protection principles.” 
This section is stating that if the data is not anonymised, then when the content provider is delivering personal data, the application could be in violation. 

Article 32, Section 1.b states:  "…the ability to ensure the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems and services". 
With an improperly configured PendingIntent, the app may be in violation of confidentiality if personal data is exposed by the content provider. 

Article 32, Section 2 states:  "In assessing the appropriate level of security, account shall be taken in particular of the risks that are presented by processing, in particular from accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data transmitted, stored, or otherwise processed." 
This section indicates that the application could also be in violation if personal data is being used.

With an improperly configured PendingIntent, the app may be in violation of confidentiality if personal data is exposed by the content provider.

This section indicates that the application could also be in violation if personal data is being used.

scanDetails.description: The application's methods of injected Java objects are enumerable from JavaScript.
The application is using firebase remote config services. This could allow for a change of application behavior or appearance and the app being updated and initiated by a remote backend parameter.
This application is using the Nativex advertising components.  Nativex is an app marketing agency dedicated to driving ROI for all sectors of business in a mobile-first world.
This application queries the calendar on the device potentially to obtain the current time.
The application is querying the device to obtain the Android_ID. This could facilitate tracking of the user.

compliance.riskDescription:
Article 5, Section 1 states:  "Personal data shall be: processed lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner in relation to the data subject (‘lawfulness, fairness and transparency’)." 
The app Android ID could be considered personal data and may also fall under additional GDPR regulations.  Ensure the collection of this data is legal and transparent to the user of the application. 

Article 13, Section 1 covers:  All the necessary requirements that the mobile app needs to provide the app user prior to collecting personal data.  This summary in this section includes who is collecting the data, the purpose and legal basis for collecting the data, and if any of the data is being transferred to a third party such as an advertiser or a third country.  The identity of the third party needs to be provided as well. 

Article 13, Section 2 states:  When the data is obtained the app user needs to be informed as to how long this data will be stored, where the data is to be stored, and if the data is being used to profile the user or to make automated decisions for the user.  The ability to allow the user to request the deletion of the data and a mechanism to lodge a complaint all need to be made available.  Most of these requirements should be clearly laid out in the privacy policy. 

Article 13 Privacy Information:  The Privacy Information should be made available from the app store before download. Once the app is installed, the privacy information needs to be easily accessible from within the app. The recommendation is that it should never be more than “two taps away” (e.g. by including a “Privacy” option in the app menu). 

Article 25, Section 1 states:  "…both at the time of the determination of the means for processing and at the time of the processing itself, implement appropriate technical and organisational measures, such as pseudonymisation, which are designed to implement data-protection principles.”
If personal data is being sent off device by this component, then ensure it is pseudonymised.

scanDetails.description: App uses SQLite Database and execute raw SQL query. If this query executes untrusted user input then the condition for SQL Injection exists.

compliance.registrationNumber: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection')

compliance.riskDescription: The application is using the rawQuery() or the rawQueryWithFactory() method calls. The SQL being passed to these methods needs to be reviewed to ensure proper SQL sanitization to avoid SQL Injection.

scanDetails.description: The application is performing a check to determine if the application has a debugger attached. Often this is used as a binary protection measure but can also be implemented to hide malicious activity from reverse engineering.

compliance.riskDescription: The app prevents debugging and/or detects, and responds to, a debugger being attached. All available debugging protocols must be covered.

compliance.riskDescription: All inputs from external sources and the user are validated and if necessary sanitized. This includes data received via the UI, IPC mechanisms such as intents, custom URLs, and network sources.

This application has an unprotected exported Service. If a Service is exported and not protected with strong permissions, then any application can start and bind to the Service. Depending on the duties of a particular Service, it may leak information or perform unauthorized tasks.

scanDetails.description: The activity has an intent-filter that is associated with URI with specified schema also known as 'deep-link'.

compliance.riskDescription: The app does not export sensitive functionality via custom URL schemes, unless these mechanisms are properly protected.

scanDetails.description: String.xml file may contain hardcoded credentials or sensitive information

The application uses PendingIntent. By giving a PendingIntent to another application, it grants the right to perform the operation specified with the same permissions and identity of the calling app. The base Intent supplied needs the component name explicitly set to one of the calling app's own components. Without the explicitly named component the PendingIntent could be misdirected.

compliance.riskDescription:
Article 25, Section 1 states: "…both at the time of the determination of the means for processing and at the time of the processing itself, implement appropriate technical and organisational measures, such as pseudonymisation, which are designed to implement data-protection principles".
This section is stating that if the data is not anonymised, then when the PendingIntent is associated with personal data, the application could be in violation. 

Article 32, Section 1.b states:  "…the ability to ensure the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems and services". 
With an improperly configured PendingIntent, the app may be in violation of confidentiality if personal data is being pushed by the exposed PendingIntent.  Additionally, integrity and availability could be questioned if the vulnerability can be exploited to perform a DOS (denial of service) attack. 
 
Article 32, Section 2 states:  "In assessing the appropriate level of security, account shall be taken in particular of the risks that are presented by processing, in particular from accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data transmitted, stored, or otherwise processed." 
This section indicates that the application could also be in violation if personal data is being used.

This section is stating that if the data is not anonymised, then when the PendingIntent is associated with personal data, the application could be in violation. 

Article 32, Section 1.b states:  "…the ability to ensure the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems and services". 
With an improperly configured PendingIntent, the app may be in violation of confidentiality if personal data is being pushed by the exposed PendingIntent.  Additionally, integrity and availability could be questioned if the vulnerability can be exploited to perform a DOS (denial of service) attack. 
 
Article 32, Section 2 states:  "In assessing the appropriate level of security, account shall be taken in particular of the risks that are presented by processing, in particular from accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data transmitted, stored, or otherwise processed." 
This section indicates that the application could also be in violation if personal data is being used.

scanDetails.description: The application can load external libraries from untrusted sources or untrusted environments that could alter the intent of the application.

The detected application's broadcast receiver is dynamically registered in the code and not protected by signature permission in the AndroidManifest.xml file and is exported.
All of the receivers are non-exported by default, unless the android:exported attribute is set to "true" or an intent-filter element is defined.
The android:exported sets Whether the broadcast receiver can receive messages from non-system sources outside its application — "true" if it can, and "false" if not.

The broadcast receiver is registered to a custom private non-system implicit intent action which enables an attacker to broadcast arbitrary data to the exported receiver. 

To secure receivers like this, you should always declare appropriate permissions during the call to the registerReceiver method.
Broadcast receivers represent a likely exploitable component which is often used to start services, so it's highly recommended to check all of the external data is passed to them. To enable the most restrictive and therefore secure policy, you should minimize the number of exported intents by using the signature permissions.
The Android application exposes a service component for use by other applications, but might not properly restrict which applications can launch the component or access the data it contains.
The Android application exposes an activity component for use by other applications, but might not properly restrict which applications can launch the component or access the data it contains

compliance.registrationNumber: CWE-926: Improper Export of Android Application Components

scanDetails.description: Undeclared Permissions are being used by a component of the app. A malicious app can declare that permission with a normal protection level, request it and invoke the protected component of the app.

compliance.riskDescription: The app do not use only the minimum set of permissions necessary. An undeclared Permissions is being used by an app component.

scanDetails.description: The application was found to contain obfuscated method names. This can be used by legitimate developers to protect intellectual property and used by others to conceal potentially malicious code.

compliance.riskCategory: Develop and maintain secure systems and applications
compliance.riskDescription:
The application layer is high-risk and may be targeted by both internal and external threats. 
Requirements 6.5.1 through 6.5.10 are the minimum controls that should be in place, and organizations should incorporate the relevant secure coding practices as applicable to the particular technology in their environment.
Application developers should be properly trained to identify and resolve issues related to these (and other) common coding vulnerabilities. Having staff knowledgeable of secure coding guidelines should minimize the number of security vulnerabilities introduced through poor coding practices. Training for developers may be provided in-house or by third parties and should be applicable for technology used.
As industry-accepted secure coding practices change, organizational coding practices and developer training should likewise be updated to address new threats—for example, memory scraping attacks.
The vulnerabilities identified in 6.5.1 through 6.5.10 provide a minimum baseline. It is up to the organization to remain up to date with vulnerability trends and incorporate appropriate measures into their secure coding practices.
Obfuscation is applied to programmatic defenses, which in turn impede de-obfuscation via dynamic analysis.

scanDetails.description: This application exposes source level metadata symbols and fails the testing outlined by OWASP Mobile Top 10 covered under category M9: Reverse Engineering

compliance.registrationNumber: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor

compliance.riskDescription: Implement technical policies and procedures for electronic information systems that maintain electronic protected health information to allow access only to those persons or software programs that have been granted access rights as specified in §164.308(a)(4).

compliance.riskCategory: Develop and maintain secure systems and applications
compliance.webLink:
Address common coding vulnerabilities in software-development processes as follows:
• Train developers at least annually in upto-date secure coding techniques, including how to avoid common coding vulnerabilities.
• Develop applications based on secure coding guidelines.

The app utilizes the Java.io.File delete() method to perform a file deletion. This method is not a secure method of file deletion. Because the Android API does not provide a method to perform secure file deletion operations it is suggested to overwrite the file with random characters before performing the file delete operation when sensitive data is involved. Files are only marked for deletion and can be recovered using third-party utilities on a rooted device.
The application is using an insecure random number generator.

compliance.registrationNumber: CWE-330: Use of Insufficiently Random Values

compliance.riskDescription: All random values are generated using a sufficiently secure random number generator.

compliance.riskDescription: The app uses cryptographic primitives that are appropriate for the particular use-case, configured with parameters that adhere to industry best practices.

scanDetails.description: This app uses Java code reflection. Reflection enables a Java program to analyze and modify itself. An attacker can create unexpected control flow paths through the application, potentially by-passing security checks. Exploitation of this weakness can result in a limited form of code injection.

This app has the functionality to install additional apps.
This app uses a cryptographically strong random number generator (RNG).
The app uses the 'proceed()' method during SSL error handling. This can allow the connection to be established even if the SSL certificate is invalid. This is not a recommended practice.

compliance.registrationNumber: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor
CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints

compliance.riskDescription:
Article 25, Section 1 states:  "…both at the time of the determination of the means for processing and at the time of the processing itself, implement appropriate technical and organisational measures, such as pseudonymisation, which are designed to implement data-protection principles". 
If personal data is being sent off device then it should be pseudonymised. If the SSL traffic is compromised then any personal data harvested will not be useful to the attacker. 

Article 32, Section 1. states:  "…the pseudonymisation and encryption of personal data". 
Article 32, Section 1.b states:  "The ability to ensure the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems and services". 
Using the proceed() method degrades confidence that the confidentiality and integrity of the communication can be trusted. 

Article 32, Section 2 states:  "In assessing the appropriate level of security account shall be taken in particular of the risks that are presented by processing, in particular from accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to personal data transmitted, stored or otherwise processed." 
This states that the application could also be in violation if personal data is being transmitted.  Using the proceed() method allows communications to occur even if a secure channel cannot be created.

If personal data is being sent off device then it should be pseudonymised. If the SSL traffic is compromised then any personal data harvested will not be useful to the attacker.

Using the proceed() method degrades confidence that the confidentiality and integrity of the communication can be trusted.

This states that the application could also be in violation if personal data is being transmitted.  Using the proceed() method allows communications to occur even if a secure channel cannot be created.
Implement technical security measures to guard against unauthorized access to electronic protected health information that is being transmitted over an electronic communications network.

compliance.riskCategory: Develop and maintain secure systems and applications
compliance.riskDescription: Applications that fail to adequately encrypt network traffic using strong cryptography are at increased risk of being compromised and exposing cardholder data. If an attacker is able to exploit weak cryptographic processes, they may be able to gain control of an application or even gain clear-text access to encrypted data.

Data is encrypted on the network using TLS. The secure channel is used consistently throughout the app.

The TLS settings are in line with current best practices, or as close as possible if the mobile operating system does not support the recommended standards.

The 'proceed()' method is utilized in the WebView during SSL error handling. This can allow the connection to be established even if the SSL Certificate is invalid. It is not recommended to proceed past SSL errors and this method should generally not be used.

scanDetails.description: This app requests permissions during runtime.
This app utilizes the fingerprint reader on the device.

compliance.riskDescription:
Article 5, Section 1 states:  "Personal data shall be: processed lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner in relation to the data subject (‘lawfulness, fairness and transparency’)." 
If the location data is considered personal data then additional GDPR regulations apply to ensure the data captured is legal and transparent to the user of the application. 

Article 13, Section 1 covers:  All the necessary requirements that the mobile app needs to provide the app user prior to collecting Location data.  This summary in this section includes who is collecting the data, the purpose and legal basis for collecting the data, and if any of the data is being transferred to a third party such as an advertiser or a third country. The identity of the third party needs to be provided as well. 

Article 13, Section 2 states:   When the data is obtained the app user needs to be informed as to how long this data will be stored, where the data is to be stored, and if the data is being used to profile the user or to make automated decisions for the user.  The ability to allow the user to request the deletion of the data and a mechanism to lodge a complaint all need to be made available.  Most of these requirements should be clearly laid out in the privacy policy. 

Article 13 Privacy Information:  The Privacy Information should be made available from the app store before download.  Once the app is installed, the privacy information needs to be easily accessible from within the app.  The recommendation is that it should never be more than “two taps away” (e.g. by including a “Privacy” option in the app menu). 

Article 25, Section 1 states:  "…both at the time of the determination of the means for processing and at the time of the processing itself, implement appropriate technical and organisational measures, such as pseudonymisation, which are designed to implement data-protection principles.”
If personal data is being sent off device, then it should be pseudonymised.

Article 13, Section 1 covers:  All the necessary requirements that the mobile app needs to provide the app user prior to collecting Location data.  This summary in this section includes who is collecting the data, the purpose and legal basis for collecting the data, and if any of the data is being transferred to a third party such as an advertiser or a third country. The identity of the third party needs to be provided as well. 

Article 13, Section 2 states:   When the data is obtained the app user needs to be informed as to how long this data will be stored, where the data is to be stored, and if the data is being used to profile the user or to make automated decisions for the user.  The ability to allow the user to request the deletion of the data and a mechanism to lodge a complaint all need to be made available.  Most of these requirements should be clearly laid out in the privacy policy. 

Article 13 Privacy Information:  The Privacy Information should be made available from the app store before download.  Once the app is installed, the privacy information needs to be easily accessible from within the app.  The recommendation is that it should never be more than “two taps away” (e.g. by including a “Privacy” option in the app menu). 

Article 25, Section 1 states:  "…both at the time of the determination of the means for processing and at the time of the processing itself, implement appropriate technical and organisational measures, such as pseudonymisation, which are designed to implement data-protection principles.”
If personal data is being sent off device, then it should be pseudonymised.

scanDetails.description: access to system-wide possibly writable locations.

compliance.riskDescription:
The application shall not write user-modifiable files to directories that contain executable files unless explicitly directed by the user to do so.

The evaluator shall run the program, mimicking normal usage, and note where all files are written. The evaluator shall ensure that there are no executable files stored under /data/data/package/ where package is the Java package of the application.

scanDetails.description: This application does contain rooted device detection functionality.
This application uses the AES cipher block chaining mode for encryption or decryption.
This app enables remote debugging of web layouts and JavaScript code running inside WebViews.
Returns the unique subscriber ID, for example, the IMSI for a GSM phone.
